answers.text:
A performance evaluation system should be focused on behaviors, as behaviors drive results.  The evaluation of those behaviors should only be compared to established standards (developed through a job analysis), not to behaviors/performance of other employees.  The individual either performs at the standard or above or below and should be rated as such. As Barry mentions, the key to successful performance evaluations is education for the evaluators - they need to fully understand the performance standards and how to compare their observations against the standards, and then be honest about what they observe.  I'm trying really hard to think of the benefits of utilizing a bell curve system. You mention it was successful in driving expectations - I would suggest that is established through performance standards and goal setting.  I recently completed a project on a new performance evaluation system, I would be happy to discuss further if you are interested.

answers.author: Brian Heck
answers.text:
Our performance evluation system is based on individual results and achievement of established expectations established between the employee and their supervisor. I have to agree with the previous two respondents that an employee evluation must be based on what the employee accomplished during the year, how they met the expectations of the supervisor, how they met and demonstrated the core values of the organization, etc.

answers.author: Barry Crook
answers.text:
Why would you want to ration acknowledgement of good performance by imposing some kind of normal curve on it? If the evaluations are done "right" let the results speak for themselves. If you are imposing the normal curve on a non-normal set of observations, you are creating a disincentive on performance. Train managers to be honest in their evaluations and let the chips fall where they may.

author: James Ley
text: Is anyone using the bell curve as a means of setting guidance for emplyee evaluation systems?  We have been doing so for four years (and it has worked to drive expectations) and now find that with layoffs and other reorganizations that it may be time to move to something else - like a semi bell curve.  I am interested in feedback from others as to the use of the bell curve, results and any transformational next steps?
title: Employee Performance Evaluations
